001package io.jstach.jstache;
002
003import java.io.OutputStream;
004import java.lang.annotation.Documented;
005import java.lang.annotation.ElementType;
006import java.lang.annotation.Retention;
007import java.lang.annotation.RetentionPolicy;
008import java.lang.annotation.Target;
009
010/**
011 * Compiler flags that are subject to change. Use at your own risk.
012 * <p>
013 * <strong>Flags maybe added without a major version change unlike the rest of the
014 * API.</strong>
015 * <p>
016 * Order of flag lookup and precedence is as follows:
017 * <ol>
018 * <li>type annotated with JStache and this annotation.
019 * <li>enclosing class (of type annotated with JStache) with this annotation with inner to
020 * outer order.
021 * <li>package annotated with this annotation.
022 * <li>module annotated with this annotation.
023 * <li>annotation processor compiler arg options (<code>-A</code>). The flags are
024 * lowercased and prefixed with "<code>jstache.</code>"</li>
025 * </ol>
026 * <em>The flags are NOT combined but rather the first found dictates the flags set or not
027 * (including empty)</em>
028 *
029 * @author agentgt
030 * @apiNote the retention policy is purposely {@link RetentionPolicy#SOURCE} as these
031 * flags only impact compiling of the template.
032 */
033@Retention(RetentionPolicy.SOURCE)
034@Target({ ElementType.MODULE, ElementType.PACKAGE, ElementType.TYPE })
035@Documented
036public @interface JStacheFlags {
037
038        /**
039         * Compiler flags that will be used on for this model.
040         * @return flags
041         * @see JStacheFlags
042         */
043        Flag[] flags();
044
045        /**
046         * Compiler flags. Besides setting with {@link JStacheFlags} the flags are also
047         * available as annotation processor options but are prefixed with
048         * "<code>jstache.</code>" and lowercased
049         * <p>
050         * For example {@link Flag#DEBUG} would be: <code>-Ajstache.debug=true/false</code>
051         *
052         * @apiNote SUBJECT TO CHANGE!
053         * @author agentgt
054         *
055         */
056        public enum Flag {
057
058                /**
059                 * This will produce additional logging that is sent to standard out while the
060                 * annotation processor runs (not during runtime).
061                 */
062                DEBUG,
063                /**
064                 * Per mustache spec dotted names can actually not exist at all for inverted
065                 * sections. This flag disables that so that a compiler failure will happen if the
066                 * fields are missing.
067                 *
068                 * For example assume "missing" is not present on "data" as in data has no field
069                 * or method called "missing".
070                 *
071                 * <pre>
072                 * {{^data.missing}}
073                 * {{/data.missing}}
074                 * </pre>
075                 *
076                 * Normally the above will compile just fine per the spec but this can lead to
077                 * bugs. To not allow what the spec calls "dotted broken chains" you can use this
078                 * flag.
079                 */
080                NO_INVERTED_BROKEN_CHAIN,
081
082                /**
083                 * <strong>EXPERIMENTAL:</strong> Normally falsey is either empty list, boolean
084                 * false, or <code>null</code>. This flag disables <code>null</code> as a falsey
085                 * check.
086                 *
087                 * For example when opening a section like: <pre><code class="language-hbs">
088                 * {{#myNonNull}}
089                 * Hi!
090                 * {{/myNonNull}}
091                 * </code> </pre>
092                 *
093                 * JStachio would produce code that checks if <code>myNonNull</code> is null as
094                 * well as iterate if it is a list or check if true if it is a boolean.
095                 *
096                 * <p>
097                 * However null checking will still be done if JStachio can find a
098                 * {@link ElementType#TYPE_USE} annotation with the {@link Class#getSimpleName()}
099                 * of <code>Nullable</code> on the type that is being accessed as a section. This
100                 * follows <a href="https://github.com/jspecify/jspecify">JSpecify rules</a> but
101                 * not other nullable annotations like
102                 * <a href="https://spotbugs.github.io/">SpotBugs</a> that are not
103                 * {@link ElementType#TYPE_USE}.
104                 *
105                 * <h4>Benefits</h4>
106                 *
107                 * The advantages of disabling null checking are:
108                 * <ul>
109                 * <li>Failing fast instead of just not rendering something which may make finding
110                 * bugs easier.</li>
111                 * <li>Less generated code which maybe easier to read</li>
112                 * <li>Avoid warnings of superfluous null checking by static analysis tools</li>
113                 * <li>Possible slight improvement of performance</li>
114                 * </ul>
115                 *
116                 * <h4>Caveats</h4>
117                 *
118                 * <h5>JDK Bug</h5> Because of JDK bug:
119                 * <a href="https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8225377">JDK-8225377</a> this
120                 * <em>nullable detection will only work if the type that is being checked is
121                 * currently within the same compile boundary as the JStache model being
122                 * analyzed!</em>
123                 *
124                 * <h5>Manually checking for null</h5> If JStachio cannot detect that the type is
125                 * nullable because it is not annotated or because of the aforementioned JDK bug
126                 * then it will conclude that it can never be null and thus you will be unable to
127                 * use section like conditions to check if is null. One workaround is to use a
128                 * custom {@link JStacheLambda} to check for null.
129                 *
130                 * @apiNote This is currently experimental and a flag because of the JDK bug. In
131                 * the future more comprehensive support will be put in {@link JStacheConfig}.
132                 */
133                NO_NULL_CHECKING,
134
135                /**
136                 * If set the templates will have pre-encoded bytes of the static parts of the
137                 * template and the generated {@link JStacheType#JSTACHIO} code will implement
138                 * <code>io.jstach.jstachio.Template.EncodedTemplate</code> which will allow
139                 * writing binary to an {@link OutputStream}.
140                 */
141                PRE_ENCODE;
142
143        }
144
145}
